name: Ruby 2.0 or higher supported
body:
On this version it was included support for latest Rubies > 2.0

It also contains new and working examples.

As easy as

``` ruby
planet init

planet generate
```

Enjoy!

name: Tags, categories and Sanitization
body:
Sometimes it is just easier to group your posts under a certain category or simple tag it.
You can now use:

``` ruby
{{ blog_categories }}    # => "programming planet"
{{ blog_tags }}          # => "go ruby jekyll"
```

Thanks to @pinoss 

Also for the paranoia among us, you have an option to sanitize HTML fragments in the post content. It is set by default to false.
But if you set

``` ruby
sanitize_html: true
```

It will sanitize the content based on https://github.com/rgrove/sanitize/.
If your site hosts other service you may want to turn this on.
Thanks to @scott-linder 

Best.

name: Full access to blog's and post's RSS Data
body:
There are now two objects that can be accessed from your octopress/jekyll templates which contain the  RSS data parse object used inside planet for each feed. 

```
{{ post_rss_data }}         #=> Contains data for the current post's entry in the RSS feed. Ej: {{ post_rss_data.title }} 

{{ blog_rss_data }}          #=> Contains the full RSS data parsed from the blog. 
```

There is no obvious way to use this generically as this improvement is meant to expose data that users might want access from their custom templates, the use case that prompted me to add this feature was a user that wanted access to thumbnails from a blog as can be seen in issue #38.

Anyway, this change should make planet itself more flexible so I hope other users can enjoy that as well. 

Cheers everyone!

name: More flexible output format
body:
Thanks to [@tamouse](https://github.com/tamouse) making [two pull requests](https://github.com/pote/planet.rb/pulls?direction=desc&page=1&sort=created&state=closed) in the last few days I'm releasing a new minor version of planet with the following goodies:

### Customize the file extension of planet's output.

It used to be hardcored to markdown, and while that's still the default it is useful to be able to export as html. 

You can specify the file extension used like so:

```
▸ planet generate -e html
▸ planet generate --extension html
```

### post_url variable fixed.

One of the variables available in the templates (`post_url`) was broken, and as it's not one that's included in the default post template, but that's fixed now.

So once again: huge thanks to Tamouse for her hard work and contribution. I hope the new additions are of use to everyone else. :)

name: Whitelisting post categories/tags and fault tolerance
body:
Thanks to [Srihari Sriraman](https://github.com/ssrihari) we have some new goodies on planet.rb! 

The first feature is: whitelisted tags, a lot of people had asked for it and I was continue to push it down the road since I couldn't find a universal way to do it for all feeds, but Srihari sent a PR that takes care of it for most use cases, so I think it's good enough for general usage.

This is how it works: you add a `whitelisted tags` field on your `planet.yml` file, if left empty this will mean all tags are allowed.

``` yaml
planet:
    posts_directory: source/_posts/                 # => Posts text files will be written into this directory
    templates_directory: source/_layouts/       # => Planet specific layouts will be saved here, I suggest that it matches your Octopress/Jekyll layout directory.
    whitelisted_tags: []                                   # => Only posts that are tagged with any of these tags will be imported
```

Pretty awesome! Hope you will find it useful.

The other PR is regarding failure to fetch blog posts, planet used to simply crash and ask you to retry the whole process which wasn't all that smart, thanks to Srihari we now have tolerance to failure in fetching (and the code for that is super tidy)

All in all, I thought I'd bump the version of planet and release all this for everyone. Happy planetin'! :dancers:
